results.title: From Graz to Glenroy
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Elfrieda Senycia and Viv Mehes
results.brief_description: This story explores the journey of migration from Austria to Australia for Elfrida and her husband. As they rebuild life in a new country they deal with triumps and disappointments including the humiliation of never having their qualifications recognised in Australia.

results.title: Game Masters: Yuji Naka interview
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, ACMI Media Studio, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Yuji Naka is a videogame designer and programmer, best known as the former head of Sonic Team, where he was the lead programmer of the original ‘Sonic the Hedgehog’. Naka reveals his initial desire to make arcade games and the influence that Yu Suzuki has had on his career as a programmer. Since 2006 he has been the head of Prope, an independent game company he founded after leaving SEGA.
Yuji gives great insights into the development and creation of ‘Sonic the Hedgehog 1 and 2’, ‘Nights into Dreams’ and ‘Chu Chu Rocket’.
NB: This interview was conducted in Yuji Naka’s native language of Japanese and features English subtitles. Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: In conversation with Julian Rosefeldt
results.brief_description:
ACMI Curator Sarah Tutton speaks to acclaimed contemporary artist Julian Rosefeldt, offering a unique insight into his creative process.

German-born Rosefeldt makes visually opulent film and video installations. Following the exhibition of his 5-channel work ‘American Night’, Julian’s work ‘The Shift’ appeared as part of ACMI’s ‘Star Voyager’ exhibition in 2011. Rather than focussing on the exhibited work, Rosefeldt discusses his previous work, themes and influences, by way of prelude to his current projects.

This conversation provides the rare opportunity to hear one of the world’s most renowned moving image artists discuss his remarkable work.

results.brief_description: Memories of the early years of Moomba, particularly of the pageant and my involvement in those early years. A digital story created to celebrate 50 years of Melbourne Moomba Water Fest.

results.title: River of my Life
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Amira Sabanovic
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Amira describes the course her life has taken - from the ravages of War in her homeland through to the hardships of a refugee’s life in both Europe and Australia before finding acceptance and fulfillment through a supportive workplace.

results.title: Leaving Tropeoulhos
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Anastasia Solomidis
results.brief_description: Anastasia and her husband lived in a village in Greece. One day a government official arrived to ask whether they would consider migrating to Australia. They talked about it and decided that they had better take up this opportunity to improve their lives and provide opportunities for their children.

results.title: Game Masters: Yu Suzuki interview
results.creator_credit: Richard Greenhalgh, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Yu Suzuki talks about his body of work which is one of the most diverse in the industry, ranging from the adrenalin rushes of his early arcade hits ‘Space Harrier’ (1985) and ‘Hang-On’ (1985) to the console adventure epic ‘Shenmue’ (1999).

As the pioneer of immersive, full-body arcade games, Suzuki has never been afraid to explore fantasy, reality and every shade of virtual experience in between.

In 1999, Suzuki moved away from arcades to create ‘Shenmue’ (1999), an open-world adventure for the Dreamcast. ‘Shenmue’ was recognised at the time as one of the most expansive and detailed videogames ever made; it pioneered the ‘open city’ subgenre of open-world games.

NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: David and Jennifer Learn Their Kerb Drill
results.creator_credit: Rhonda Small, John Martin-Jones, Australian Road Safety Council and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: David and Jennifer are sent on messages to a shop across a busy street. Their mother carefully explains the meaning of the traffic lights. They sing a safety song to remember the newly learnt rules.

results.title: In conversation with Chris Dercon and Kaat Debo
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
This free talk was held at ACMI on 17 July 2013 to celebrate two exhibitions, ACMI’s ‘Hollywood Costume’ and RMIT University Design Hub’s ‘Walter Van Beirendonck; Dream the World Awake’.

Chris Dercon, director of London’s Tate Modern, and Kaat Debo, director/curator at Mode Museum in Antwerp, discussed the particulars of exhibiting fashion and costume, and explored the dialogue between art and fashion.

They investigated the ways a curator can animate clothes through multisensory and multimedia experiences, Dercon and Debo looked at the approaches taken by curators, identifying interesting narratives for exhibiting garments and took the audience behind-the-seams of fashion and costume exhibiting.

results.title: Kylie
results.brief_description: A story about family relationships and two sisters growing up without a father. Separated by distance, emotionally and physically, Scarlett expresses her thoughts and feelings about her older sister Kylie. Change, it seems, is inevitable but change can also inspire.
results.description: A story about family relationships and two sisters growing up without a father. Separated by distance, emotionally and physically, Scarlett expresses her thoughts and feelings about her older sister Kylie. Change, it seems, is inevitable but change can also inspire.
